# 731: The Keynesian prescription which I was taught at Clark University in the 1950's called for the pursuit of a countercyclical fiscal policy in both bad times and good times, with the surpluses run up in good times offsetting and paying for the deficits run in bad times. It struck me as extremely sensible and conservative, and I graduated in 1959 with great admiration for Keynes' good sense. Only later did I realize that in the real world, where economics is subordinate to politics, Keynes' teachings are routinely and shamelessly misused to justify the running of deficits in both bad and good times. This is not Keynes' fault; in a better world than this, his prescription would undoubtedly work. The claim that he endorsed constant and growing deficits and that the resulting infinite debt is either a good thing or at least harmless would have horrified him.

I don't think John Maynard Keynes and Dr. Krugman are on the same wavelength at all.

Pardon if these things have already been considered:

1. A brain scan. Children can bump their heads and cause damage at an early age. Best to find out now.

2. Thyroid tests. After 10 years of frequent manic episodes that pretty much destroyed our family, I had my daughter's thyroid tested and it was almost non-functional. Since then, she has been on thyroid medication and over the past 10 years, she has had exactly one minor episode. She also is very carbohydrate sensitive and has to eat a modified Atkins diet.

It may not work, but sometimes their is a physical basis and it cannot hurt to try.

It never fails that politicians are long on rhetoric and short on action. Anyone with a sixth grade education could tell you that combining spending cuts with revenue increases will pay down any debt faster than doing either one alone. But no one in Washington wants to hear this cause it would so simple and effective. Maybe it will take an outsider (another Lincoln?) to come in and demand action. Right now, I don't see how either Mr. Obama (who has to overcome his own ideals of being a democratic leader) or Mr. Romney (who has to overcome the Tea Party's perception of him as a liberal) will save the country. Of course, we could just ignore the iceberg and wait until the ship is almost under. At which time, Captain Smith will announce to the passengers still on board that it's "everyman for himself!" just before he dives into his own icy grave.

"Everyone needs to get real. Supply-side economics doesn't work alone; demand-side economics doesn't work alone. Supply-side and demand-side needs to be in balance. Spending cuts alone cannot solve the deficit; revenue increases alone cannot solve the deficit. Revenue and spending have to be in balance. Unfettered capitalism doesn't work; oligarchical socialism as practiced in the Soviet Union didn't work. Capitalism which is governed by reasonable regulations protecting the well-being of the people can work.

Responsible politicians, business-people,workers, consumers, students, and everyone needs to test their actions against two questions: (1) Is what I'm doing good for me, and (2) Is what I'm doing good for society? We need accurate information and rational discourse to find the answers, not the lies and spin which is being spewed forth from many in the media and from politicians."

Separately, can someone tell the WPS owners to stop badmouthing WUSA? Those owners wanted to make money too ... And much of their $100 million capital has benefitted WPS.

There is very little discussion about mental health issues, outside the professional discussion about treatment. This is definitely an area where people are ill informed, but make a judgement anyway. Africa has the compounded poverty, deprivation element and the tragedy is often compounded by tribal conflict or gangster type government.
In the West we are presumed to be enlightened and caring, but see mental illness as a weakness and in the domain of the inadequate. ME suffers are desperate to distance their suffering from that of the mentally ill, who they see as having inferior make up and a lower class of people. In the last century, soldiers who had become mentally ill from shell shock, and no longer in control of their minds, were shot as deserters.
Today traumatic stress is a recognized mentally distress and receives treatment. Many British and American soldiers will have been hospitalized with this condition. The human psyche can be traumatized in civilian life. Certainly women who are violated are at extreme risk of sufferring acute trauma.
There is evil in this world and individuals who are weakened by sufferring and horrific treatment can have their minds acutely disturbed by mental illness. Those who treat them may have medical qualifications, but many are just doing a job of work. It takes a unique individual to comprehend the sufferring of the mentally ill.
It is possible to return from this vale of tears, but as the article reveals circumstance is crucial to recovery. Television portrays mental illness as something that can be cured within a few weeks of treatment, but many never fully recover.
Our materialistic world view,often has little or no patience for the perceived stigma of mental illness. In the West as a society, we have seen rises in mental illness, some might say casualties of a rat race way of life.

I would like to add to Mr. Berkeley's comment of July 27th. Another reason for the numerical decline of American doctors is the fact that the profession is so much more difficult and frustrating to practice properly due to a host of non medical factors, such as our dysfunctional delivery system. I base this solely on my experience of 33 years in practice. I am not sophisticated enough to know how to improve medicine in the US. I leave that to people like Dr. Andrew Patterson who is not only a leading educator here, but also brings talented teams of surgeons and anesthesiologists from his Stanford University to Gitwe Hospital each year, the African home of our medical school. I do feel I can help make a difference in Rwanda, however. Africa has 25% of the world's medical needs and 3% of health care providers, percentages reflected in Rwanda. A private medical school is going up to help address this problem directly, and contributions to the Kigali Medical University Foundation (KMUF.org) go 100% to aid this cause in a highly efficient manner.
I would like to embarrassedly thank my friend Guy Mastrion for his words. Guy and his firm, Palio (www.Palio.com), have been very generous to KMUF. Unfortunately, only my late mother could believe his comments.
John H. Streit, MD
President, Kigali Medical University Foundation
